content: Praise Her A Goddess for Invoking Courage in Difficult Times Cultivating confidence and skill with the Hindu goddess Durga Lisa Marie Blocked Unblock Follow Following Apr 24 Illustration: Cat Finnie D urga is the Hindu goddess of protection, justice, and doing the right thing. As a warrior goddess, she faces each challenge with strength and conviction no matter how dire the situation may seem. She’s the goddess to call when you need help with a challenging person or time in your life. It doesn’t matter if you’ve gotten yourself into a mess, as we often are the culprits in our own dramas; Durga will be there to help. She’s also an activist and represents the energy behind the #MeToo movement. She’s an advocate for the environment and she speaks for any disenfranchised group that needs a voice. The story of Durga The three gods of the Hindu Trinity are Vishnu, Brahma, and Shiva. Historically, they called on Durga to save the world and the heavens from a half-demon, half-buffalo tyrant who had become too powerful. Brahma had granted the demon immortality from all men and gods as a reward for his devoted meditation practice. But the tyrant was using this boon to cause chaos and destruction. He could not be stopped by the three most powerful gods; only a woman could defeat the tyrant and bring order back to the universe. That woman was Durga. The three gods asked Durga to destroy the demon and his army. It’s important to note that in this story, Durga knew about the chaos the demon was causing, but she only came to help when called upon. That’s important in your life as well. The goddess wants you to petition her for help. She’s the voice inside your head telling you to face the challenge and deal with it now. Durga is dark and strong with long, flowing hair and three eyes. She has eight arms that hold the weapons the gods bestowed upon her to defeat the demon. She holds a spear, mace, discus, bow, and sword in five of her hands. The remaining three hold a conch for sound, a lotus for fertility, and a rosary for prayer. In the story, the goddess confronted the demon wearing a sexy red sari that showed off all of her curves. She was decorated with gold bangles, rings, and a statement necklace. Best of all, she came to meet the enemy riding on a lion. What a way to make an entrance! Before realizing that Durga was there to destroy him and bring order to the world, the demon wanted to take her as one of his wives. Instead, with the help of her sister goddesses, Durga killed the demon and his vengeful army, thus restoring the world and the heavens to their natural order. How Durga plays a role in modern society I like to think of Durga as the force behind the expression “put your big girl pants on.” She’s the feminine energy (also known as shakti ) that will guide you through difficult situations tactfully and righteously. Many of us are more inclined to take a passive position, but Durga reminds us that we don’t need to be passive. She gets shit done and she does so lovingly, in the spirit of protection and justice. She’s here to do what she knows is right and necessary. We all have difficult situations in our lives. It’s easy to avoid or delay addressing these situations because they’re uncomfortable. However, Durga reminds us that we can only sidestep an issue for so long. In fact, the issue is likely to grow stronger if we ignore it. She’s the voice inside your head telling you to face the challenge and deal with it now. And if you’re like me, you might still respond by saying “I’ll do it tomorrow.” I suspect it’s easier for many of us to channel our Durga energy when we’re protecting someone else, whether it’s a child, a loved one, or a cause we’re passionate about. If my children were being bullied or needed help, I would jump in without hesitation. It can be more difficult to ask for help on my own behalf — but we can’t help others if our own world is collapsing. Additionally, many of us have been conditioned to be people pleasers. This results in a tendency to suppress Durga energy. Standing up for what you believe in can appear off-putting in our culture, where we tend to cultivate agreeability more than conviction. However, life is not that simple; we need to develop our warrior side along with our nurturing side. We need to deal with unpleasantness in a tough but loving way, because we know it’s the right thing to do and because we are strong, intelligent, actionable women. Like every goddess, Durga has a shadow side, too. You might recognize people with too much Durga energy as bossy micromanagers or people who get offended by any and everything. Too much Durga can also result in being humorlessness and overly rigid. That’s not great, so it’s important for Durga energy to be balanced. How Durga works in my life Durga is not a goddess I connect with easily. However, I recently spent time channeling my inner Durga to help me through a very challenging situation. About seven years ago, I tried to help my somewhat estranged father out of a difficult financial situation. Though I wanted to help, I was reluctant to get involved. I didn’t feel like I had the time, skills, or money. However, he continued to ask for help and I eventually agreed. I brought on a partner to provide business expertise and financial help. At the time, I wasn’t sure if it was the best business deal (I’m still not), but it seemed promising enough. Plus, there were no other options available and I felt like I needed both the cash and the industry knowledge. In hindsight, I can see that both my father and partner pushed me into a partnership, unbeknownst to one another, for two different reasons. My father wanted to be rescued. My partner wanted to profit. The situation has been a shitshow ever since. It’s cost me time, money, and, most importantly, peace of mind. Although my intent was to be helpful and help my father into a better situation, he continues to belittle and threaten me. I regret getting involved. Recently my father sent me an angry letter that was irrational, accusatory, and just plain scary. I wanted to burn it. Instead, I asked Durga for strength and guidance about how to proceed. I was able to calmly sit down and respond to his letter by citing the facts and letting him know that under no circumstance was he to talk to me or threaten me like that again. I explained the actions I would take if it continued. There is Durga energy running through all of us. Prior to writing my response, I was filled with dread. However, once the letter was written and sent, I felt like a huge weight was lifted from my shoulders. I was finally able to soothe the disappointed daughter in me who was still trying to demonstrate her value. Instead, I could let the smart, confident woman in me take control of the situation. The situation isn’t over, but I will keep Durga as my trusted advisor moving forward. The interesting thing about this situation is that I have the upper hand. Based on the agreement in place, I make all the decisions. And in hindsight I can see that the decisions I made were better than the alternatives. However, instead of using my power, I marginalized myself and felt intimidated, like a frightened girl. This is like Durga being armed with all of her weapons but not using them. I have weapons, too: I have a strong voice so that I can be heard; I have detachment so I can give up on the idea of being liked or considered the helpful daughter; I have the authority to be clear and forceful; I’m knowledgeable of market conditions and confident that I am making the right choices based on the information and resources available; and I’m discerning. I can make good decisions without being swayed by other self-interested motives. There is Durga energy running through all of us. Some of us have easier access to it than others, but it can be cultivated with determination and practice. I suspect there is no shortage of opportunities for us to work with Durga, as life is full of challenges and conflict. A ritual to help activate your Durga energy Let’s start with attire fit for a warrior goddess. Consider wearing the color red, and choose jewelry that makes you feel sexy and powerful. Feel free to pile it on. Light some candles in a quiet room or in your meditation space. Burn incense or diffuse an essential oil that can help you build confidence, like Frankincense or Jasmine. If you have an altar, make some offerings to Durga. It could be flowers, jewelry, food, or a tangible representation of the problem you are confronting. (For example, I would offer the provoking letter I received from my father.) Take a comfortable seat on the floor or on a meditation cushion. First, ask Durga directly for help with the situation at hand. Explain the problems and challenges you’re facing. Next, begin to visualize how Durga quickly and willingly jumped into battle and defeated the buffalo demon with confidence and skill. Imagine how Durga felt in the battle: righteous, confident, and empowered. Spend some time considering how these feelings would appear in your body. If you’re having trouble generating these feelings, consider how you would react if the situation you’re grappling with was happening to a loved one. Would that give you the impetus and strength to tackle it head on? Sit with these feelings and identify where they are showing up in your body. Spend some time there. Next, get your journal. In your dominant hand, ask yourself the following questions: What do you need to do to move forward or resolve this conflict? What weapons do you need to carry? What would you say or do if you weren’t afraid of disappointing someone? What would you say or do if you weren’t afraid of the reaction you might get? In your non-dominant hand, write down the answers to the questions and anything else that arises. Let Durga write through you. Once you’re done journaling, take some time to review what Durga wrote. Quietly absorb any insights. To end the ritual, thank Durga for her protection and guidance, then blow out the candle. I wish you courage, power, and determination on your journey.
title_html: A Goddess for Invoking Courage in Difficult Times

Praise Her

A Goddess for Invoking Courage in Difficult Times

Cultivating confidence and skill with the Hindu goddess Durga

Lisa Marie
Apr 24

Durga is the Hindu goddess of protection, justice, and doing the right thing. As a warrior goddess, she faces each challenge with strength and conviction no matter how dire the situation may seem. She’s the goddess to call when you need help with a challenging person or time in your life. It doesn’t matter if you’ve gotten yourself into a mess, as we often are the culprits in our own dramas; Durga will be there to help. She’s also an activist and represents the energy behind the #MeToo movement. She’s an advocate for the environment and she speaks for any disenfranchised group that needs a voice.

The story of Durga

The three gods of the Hindu Trinity are Vishnu, Brahma, and Shiva. Historically, they called on Durga to save the world and the heavens from a half-demon, half-buffalo tyrant who had become too powerful. Brahma had granted the demon immortality from all men and gods as a reward for his devoted meditation practice. But the tyrant was using this boon to cause chaos and destruction. He could not be stopped by the three most powerful gods; only a woman could defeat the tyrant and bring order back to the universe. That woman was Durga.

The three gods asked Durga to destroy the demon and his army. It’s important to note that in this story, Durga knew about the chaos the demon was causing, but she only came to help when called upon. That’s important in your life as well. The goddess wants you to petition her for help.

She’s the voice inside your head telling you to face the challenge and deal with it now.

Durga is dark and strong with long, flowing hair and three eyes. She has eight arms that hold the weapons the gods bestowed upon her to defeat the demon. She holds a spear, mace, discus, bow, and sword in five of her hands. The remaining three hold a conch for sound, a lotus for fertility, and a rosary for prayer.

In the story, the goddess confronted the demon wearing a sexy red sari that showed off all of her curves. She was decorated with gold bangles, rings, and a statement necklace. Best of all, she came to meet the enemy riding on a lion. What a way to make an entrance! Before realizing that Durga was there to destroy him and bring order to the world, the demon wanted to take her as one of his wives. Instead, with the help of her sister goddesses, Durga killed the demon and his vengeful army, thus restoring the world and the heavens to their natural order.

How Durga plays a role in modern society

I like to think of Durga as the force behind the expression “put your big girl pants on.” She’s the feminine energy (also known as shakti) that will guide you through difficult situations tactfully and righteously. Many of us are more inclined to take a passive position, but Durga reminds us that we don’t need to be passive. She gets shit done and she does so lovingly, in the spirit of protection and justice. She’s here to do what she knows is right and necessary.

We all have difficult situations in our lives. It’s easy to avoid or delay addressing these situations because they’re uncomfortable. However, Durga reminds us that we can only sidestep an issue for so long. In fact, the issue is likely to grow stronger if we ignore it. She’s the voice inside your head telling you to face the challenge and deal with it now. And if you’re like me, you might still respond by saying “I’ll do it tomorrow.”

I suspect it’s easier for many of us to channel our Durga energy when we’re protecting someone else, whether it’s a child, a loved one, or a cause we’re passionate about. If my children were being bullied or needed help, I would jump in without hesitation. It can be more difficult to ask for help on my own behalf — but we can’t help others if our own world is collapsing.

Additionally, many of us have been conditioned to be people pleasers. This results in a tendency to suppress Durga energy. Standing up for what you believe in can appear off-putting in our culture, where we tend to cultivate agreeability more than conviction. However, life is not that simple; we need to develop our warrior side along with our nurturing side. We need to deal with unpleasantness in a tough but loving way, because we know it’s the right thing to do and because we are strong, intelligent, actionable women.

Like every goddess, Durga has a shadow side, too. You might recognize people with too much Durga energy as bossy micromanagers or people who get offended by any and everything. Too much Durga can also result in being humorlessness and overly rigid. That’s not great, so it’s important for Durga energy to be balanced.

How Durga works in my life

Durga is not a goddess I connect with easily. However, I recently spent time channeling my inner Durga to help me through a very challenging situation. About seven years ago, I tried to help my somewhat estranged father out of a difficult financial situation. Though I wanted to help, I was reluctant to get involved. I didn’t feel like I had the time, skills, or money. However, he continued to ask for help and I eventually agreed.

I brought on a partner to provide business expertise and financial help. At the time, I wasn’t sure if it was the best business deal (I’m still not), but it seemed promising enough. Plus, there were no other options available and I felt like I needed both the cash and the industry knowledge. In hindsight, I can see that both my father and partner pushed me into a partnership, unbeknownst to one another, for two different reasons. My father wanted to be rescued. My partner wanted to profit. The situation has been a shitshow ever since. It’s cost me time, money, and, most importantly, peace of mind. Although my intent was to be helpful and help my father into a better situation, he continues to belittle and threaten me. I regret getting involved.

Recently my father sent me an angry letter that was irrational, accusatory, and just plain scary. I wanted to burn it. Instead, I asked Durga for strength and guidance about how to proceed. I was able to calmly sit down and respond to his letter by citing the facts and letting him know that under no circumstance was he to talk to me or threaten me like that again. I explained the actions I would take if it continued.

There is Durga energy running through all of us.

Prior to writing my response, I was filled with dread. However, once the letter was written and sent, I felt like a huge weight was lifted from my shoulders. I was finally able to soothe the disappointed daughter in me who was still trying to demonstrate her value. Instead, I could let the smart, confident woman in me take control of the situation. The situation isn’t over, but I will keep Durga as my trusted advisor moving forward.

The interesting thing about this situation is that I have the upper hand. Based on the agreement in place, I make all the decisions. And in hindsight I can see that the decisions I made were better than the alternatives. However, instead of using my power, I marginalized myself and felt intimidated, like a frightened girl. This is like Durga being armed with all of her weapons but not using them. I have weapons, too: I have a strong voice so that I can be heard; I have detachment so I can give up on the idea of being liked or considered the helpful daughter; I have the authority to be clear and forceful; I’m knowledgeable of market conditions and confident that I am making the right choices based on the information and resources available; and I’m discerning. I can make good decisions without being swayed by other self-interested motives.

There is Durga energy running through all of us. Some of us have easier access to it than others, but it can be cultivated with determination and practice. I suspect there is no shortage of opportunities for us to work with Durga, as life is full of challenges and conflict.

A ritual to help activate your Durga energy

Let’s start with attire fit for a warrior goddess. Consider wearing the color red, and choose jewelry that makes you feel sexy and powerful. Feel free to pile it on. Light some candles in a quiet room or in your meditation space. Burn incense or diffuse an essential oil that can help you build confidence, like Frankincense or Jasmine. If you have an altar, make some offerings to Durga. It could be flowers, jewelry, food, or a tangible representation of the problem you are confronting. (For example, I would offer the provoking letter I received from my father.)

Take a comfortable seat on the floor or on a meditation cushion. First, ask Durga directly for help with the situation at hand. Explain the problems and challenges you’re facing. Next, begin to visualize how Durga quickly and willingly jumped into battle and defeated the buffalo demon with confidence and skill. Imagine how Durga felt in the battle: righteous, confident, and empowered. Spend some time considering how these feelings would appear in your body. If you’re having trouble generating these feelings, consider how you would react if the situation you’re grappling with was happening to a loved one. Would that give you the impetus and strength to tackle it head on? Sit with these feelings and identify where they are showing up in your body. Spend some time there.

Next, get your journal. In your dominant hand, ask yourself the following questions:

  • What do you need to do to move forward or resolve this conflict?
  • What weapons do you need to carry?
  • What would you say or do if you weren’t afraid of disappointing someone?
  • What would you say or do if you weren’t afraid of the reaction you might get?

In your non-dominant hand, write down the answers to the questions and anything else that arises. Let Durga write through you.

Once you’re done journaling, take some time to review what Durga wrote. Quietly absorb any insights. To end the ritual, thank Durga for her protection and guidance, then blow out the candle.

I wish you courage, power, and determination on your journey.

title: A Goddess for Invoking Courage in Difficult Times
content_html:
Praise Her

A Goddess for Invoking Courage in Difficult Times

Cultivating confidence and skill with the Hindu goddess Durga

Lisa Marie
Apr 24

Durga is the Hindu goddess of protection, justice, and doing the right thing. As a warrior goddess, she faces each challenge with strength and conviction no matter how dire the situation may seem. She’s the goddess to call when you need help with a challenging person or time in your life. It doesn’t matter if you’ve gotten yourself into a mess, as we often are the culprits in our own dramas; Durga will be there to help. She’s also an activist and represents the energy behind the #MeToo movement. She’s an advocate for the environment and she speaks for any disenfranchised group that needs a voice.

The story of Durga

The three gods of the Hindu Trinity are Vishnu, Brahma, and Shiva. Historically, they called on Durga to save the world and the heavens from a half-demon, half-buffalo tyrant who had become too powerful. Brahma had granted the demon immortality from all men and gods as a reward for his devoted meditation practice. But the tyrant was using this boon to cause chaos and destruction. He could not be stopped by the three most powerful gods; only a woman could defeat the tyrant and bring order back to the universe. That woman was Durga.

The three gods asked Durga to destroy the demon and his army. It’s important to note that in this story, Durga knew about the chaos the demon was causing, but she only came to help when called upon. That’s important in your life as well. The goddess wants you to petition her for help.

She’s the voice inside your head telling you to face the challenge and deal with it now.

Durga is dark and strong with long, flowing hair and three eyes. She has eight arms that hold the weapons the gods bestowed upon her to defeat the demon. She holds a spear, mace, discus, bow, and sword in five of her hands. The remaining three hold a conch for sound, a lotus for fertility, and a rosary for prayer.

In the story, the goddess confronted the demon wearing a sexy red sari that showed off all of her curves. She was decorated with gold bangles, rings, and a statement necklace. Best of all, she came to meet the enemy riding on a lion. What a way to make an entrance! Before realizing that Durga was there to destroy him and bring order to the world, the demon wanted to take her as one of his wives. Instead, with the help of her sister goddesses, Durga killed the demon and his vengeful army, thus restoring the world and the heavens to their natural order.

How Durga plays a role in modern society

I like to think of Durga as the force behind the expression “put your big girl pants on.” She’s the feminine energy (also known as shakti) that will guide you through difficult situations tactfully and righteously. Many of us are more inclined to take a passive position, but Durga reminds us that we don’t need to be passive. She gets shit done and she does so lovingly, in the spirit of protection and justice. She’s here to do what she knows is right and necessary.

We all have difficult situations in our lives. It’s easy to avoid or delay addressing these situations because they’re uncomfortable. However, Durga reminds us that we can only sidestep an issue for so long. In fact, the issue is likely to grow stronger if we ignore it. She’s the voice inside your head telling you to face the challenge and deal with it now. And if you’re like me, you might still respond by saying “I’ll do it tomorrow.”

I suspect it’s easier for many of us to channel our Durga energy when we’re protecting someone else, whether it’s a child, a loved one, or a cause we’re passionate about. If my children were being bullied or needed help, I would jump in without hesitation. It can be more difficult to ask for help on my own behalf — but we can’t help others if our own world is collapsing.

Additionally, many of us have been conditioned to be people pleasers. This results in a tendency to suppress Durga energy. Standing up for what you believe in can appear off-putting in our culture, where we tend to cultivate agreeability more than conviction. However, life is not that simple; we need to develop our warrior side along with our nurturing side. We need to deal with unpleasantness in a tough but loving way, because we know it’s the right thing to do and because we are strong, intelligent, actionable women.

Like every goddess, Durga has a shadow side, too. You might recognize people with too much Durga energy as bossy micromanagers or people who get offended by any and everything. Too much Durga can also result in being humorlessness and overly rigid. That’s not great, so it’s important for Durga energy to be balanced.

How Durga works in my life

Durga is not a goddess I connect with easily. However, I recently spent time channeling my inner Durga to help me through a very challenging situation. About seven years ago, I tried to help my somewhat estranged father out of a difficult financial situation. Though I wanted to help, I was reluctant to get involved. I didn’t feel like I had the time, skills, or money. However, he continued to ask for help and I eventually agreed.

I brought on a partner to provide business expertise and financial help. At the time, I wasn’t sure if it was the best business deal (I’m still not), but it seemed promising enough. Plus, there were no other options available and I felt like I needed both the cash and the industry knowledge. In hindsight, I can see that both my father and partner pushed me into a partnership, unbeknownst to one another, for two different reasons. My father wanted to be rescued. My partner wanted to profit. The situation has been a shitshow ever since. It’s cost me time, money, and, most importantly, peace of mind. Although my intent was to be helpful and help my father into a better situation, he continues to belittle and threaten me. I regret getting involved.

Recently my father sent me an angry letter that was irrational, accusatory, and just plain scary. I wanted to burn it. Instead, I asked Durga for strength and guidance about how to proceed. I was able to calmly sit down and respond to his letter by citing the facts and letting him know that under no circumstance was he to talk to me or threaten me like that again. I explained the actions I would take if it continued.

There is Durga energy running through all of us.

Prior to writing my response, I was filled with dread. However, once the letter was written and sent, I felt like a huge weight was lifted from my shoulders. I was finally able to soothe the disappointed daughter in me who was still trying to demonstrate her value. Instead, I could let the smart, confident woman in me take control of the situation. The situation isn’t over, but I will keep Durga as my trusted advisor moving forward.

The interesting thing about this situation is that I have the upper hand. Based on the agreement in place, I make all the decisions. And in hindsight I can see that the decisions I made were better than the alternatives. However, instead of using my power, I marginalized myself and felt intimidated, like a frightened girl. This is like Durga being armed with all of her weapons but not using them. I have weapons, too: I have a strong voice so that I can be heard; I have detachment so I can give up on the idea of being liked or considered the helpful daughter; I have the authority to be clear and forceful; I’m knowledgeable of market conditions and confident that I am making the right choices based on the information and resources available; and I’m discerning. I can make good decisions without being swayed by other self-interested motives.

There is Durga energy running through all of us. Some of us have easier access to it than others, but it can be cultivated with determination and practice. I suspect there is no shortage of opportunities for us to work with Durga, as life is full of challenges and conflict.

A ritual to help activate your Durga energy

Let’s start with attire fit for a warrior goddess. Consider wearing the color red, and choose jewelry that makes you feel sexy and powerful. Feel free to pile it on. Light some candles in a quiet room or in your meditation space. Burn incense or diffuse an essential oil that can help you build confidence, like Frankincense or Jasmine. If you have an altar, make some offerings to Durga. It could be flowers, jewelry, food, or a tangible representation of the problem you are confronting. (For example, I would offer the provoking letter I received from my father.)

Take a comfortable seat on the floor or on a meditation cushion. First, ask Durga directly for help with the situation at hand. Explain the problems and challenges you’re facing. Next, begin to visualize how Durga quickly and willingly jumped into battle and defeated the buffalo demon with confidence and skill. Imagine how Durga felt in the battle: righteous, confident, and empowered. Spend some time considering how these feelings would appear in your body. If you’re having trouble generating these feelings, consider how you would react if the situation you’re grappling with was happening to a loved one. Would that give you the impetus and strength to tackle it head on? Sit with these feelings and identify where they are showing up in your body. Spend some time there.

Next, get your journal. In your dominant hand, ask yourself the following questions:

  • What do you need to do to move forward or resolve this conflict?
  • What weapons do you need to carry?
  • What would you say or do if you weren’t afraid of disappointing someone?
  • What would you say or do if you weren’t afraid of the reaction you might get?

In your non-dominant hand, write down the answers to the questions and anything else that arises. Let Durga write through you.

Once you’re done journaling, take some time to review what Durga wrote. Quietly absorb any insights. To end the ritual, thank Durga for her protection and guidance, then blow out the candle.

I wish you courage, power, and determination on your journey.
